text: Some people don’t eat meat for ethical reasons. That means that for them it’s wrong to eat meat, it’s wrong that animals should be killed for our food. But one of the reasons for being flexitarian and only eating meat once in a while is for the benefit of the planet. According to a recent report, being flexitarian is healthier for the individual but can also help to fight climate change. Now, Dr Marco Springmann is from the University of Oxford and was one of the lead authors of a major report that looked at the global food system and how it affects the climate. On the BBC Today programme he talked about what changes would be needed. Does he mention just one thing?

speaker: a combination of measuresambitious
text: We really found that a combination of measures would be needed to stay within environmental limits and those include changes towards healthier more plant-based diets, ambitious technological improvements and changes in farming management, and a reduction of food loss and waste.

speaker: Neil
text: So did he mention just one thing, Catherine?

speaker: combination of measures
text: No, not at all. He said that there would need to be a combination of measures which means 'a variety of different actions' including moving to a plant-based diet, developing technology, changing the way we farm and wasting less food.

speaker: ambitious Ambitious
text: He described the need for ambitious technological improvements. Ambitious here means the developments will have to be 'impressive, above the ordinary and not simple'. Dr Springmann was asked if we had to completely remove meat from the food that we eat to be healthy. What was his recommendation?

speaker: surveyed the literaturea luxury
text: Well, we looked … we surveyed the literature on what a healthy diet is and according to that, if you treat it as a luxury, it’s probably OK but you shouldn’t have more than one serving of red meat, which includes beef and pork, per week. So the more plant-based you go, the healthier and the lower an environmental impact it probably will be.

speaker: BBC Today programme presenter
text: And lamb is just the same…

speaker: Dr Marco Springmann
text: Yes.

text: So do we need to cut out meat entirely?

speaker: Catherine
text: He says that while a plant-based diet is certainly healthier, you could still have some red meat but only once a week.

speaker: luxuryluxury
text: Yes, he said think of it as a luxury. A luxury food is one that we really enjoy but don’t eat very often – perhaps because it’s very expensive or rare.

speaker: Catherine
text: Or delicious but very bad for us. We eat it as a treat but not every day. Springmann says we should think of red meat in the same way. It shouldn’t be a regular part of our diet.

speaker: surveyed the literature
text: Not at all, Neil. He said that they surveyed the literature. This means that as part of their report they studied different scientific research that had previously been published. Their advice is based on the evidence of those research papers.

speaker: flexitarian
text: Yes. A fruit is the part of plant that contains the seeds – so peppers, like tomatoes, pumpkins, avocados and olives are actually fruit. Well done if you got that one right. Now, our vocabulary. Our first word is flexitarian. This is the term for a diet that is mainly plant-based but can include meat occasionally.

speaker: ethicalethical
text: Our next word is ethical. This is in the context of choosing not to eat meat. Some people are vegetarian because they don’t like meat, some because they want a healthier diet and some for ethical reasons. This means that their choice is because they feel it is the right thing to do.

speaker: a combination of measures
text: The next phrase was a combination of measures. This means 'taking different actions to achieve something', not just doing one thing.

speaker: ambitiousambitious ambitious
text: We then had ambitious. If a person is ambitious, it means that they 'want to get on in life and be successful', but ambitious can also be used to describe a plan or achievement which is 'impressive and above the ordinary'.

speaker: survey the literature
text: The next phrase was to survey the literature. This means to 'study and analyse the different scientific research on a particular subject'.

speaker: luxurya luxury
text: And finally we had luxury. When talking about food, a luxury is something that we only eat occasionally as a special treat because it’s expensive or unhealthy but delicious.
